19742C0A2A314CE4BBD99CAA265097B1.description: Research career pathways in vocal jazz and music in general.

69E9C99D5E2049DE916856B3524EB56C.description: Describe how Canadian and international copyright laws affect the lives of those who work in the jazz field.

007F576627D148D4AE2C3DE1CC247637.description: Investigate the relationship between instrumental and vocal jazz, with particular emphasis on vocal performers who "imitate" insturmental sounds (e.g., Bobby McFerrin, Mark Murphy, Giacommo Gates, Louis Armstrong, Ella Fitzgerald).

E893CCF94D0C46EF934372AB9412FA92.description: Identify influential vocal ensembles, investigate why these performers are so influential and listen to their music. Give special attention to performers from Saskatchewan and Canada

4280B3626FDE4A42BE50EFBE717F028B.description: Evaluate the degree of influence that vocal jazz has had on other types of music with an emphasis on the music of Canada and Saskatchewan, and assess possible careers in vocal jazz and music

A7A8C427B3924CC4A27EB2080C989DBC.description: Discuss the influence of jazz (and other musics) on contemporary First Nations music.

93F85EEF75CE40829368C8A70D06B2BD.description: Research how vocal jazz artists may raise or have raised awareness of local, national and international issues (e.g., Billie Holiday singing "Strange Fruit" or Manhattan Transfer singing "Aqua").

A7B33AC6635641978300C823D4FC6E00.description: Investigate some of the challenges that vocal jazz artists with African America, First Nations, and/or mixed race heritage may have had in their daily lives, and compare to the situations faced by many groups of people today.

1F8B8BB0C939476184FD7F6A1D5E9A60.description: Explore jazz music and its performers and educators and their influence in the world.

84D4240DFDEA435D863635573890F95C.description: Explore aspects of vocal jazz such as history, performers, styles and eras through a variety of media, with a focus on Canadian or Saskatchewan jazz artists.

05D15F30C9284C269D92CCC359FE161B.description: Individually and as a group listen to recordings of vocal jazz and catagorize the music into styles, genres, periods and/or place.

B1E0851644284E33A7EB375968E350B6.description: Individually and in groups, listen to recording of vocal jazz, develop a list or understanding of the basic characteristics of different jazz styles, genres, periods and place and implement that knowledge into practice and performance.

0B113C714AC44B57BCBF031ED45F1E57.description: Develop knowledge of the different eras, genres, styles and feels of vocal jazz through listening to and.or performing the representative music.

27C01C98D4B744D3AB54BF0A043E72B5.description: Cultural/Historical (CH) Goal: Students will investigate the content and aesthetics of the arts within cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts, and understand the connection between the arts and the human experience.

4F1E704F6CCD48A0919E9B66A886359A.description: Know the value of individual practice, know how to practive, conduct an ongoing evaluation of the student's personal practice skills, and implement a plan for improvement.

2251305A7B154E1BA4B22050A188CC13.description: With assistance as necessary, demonstrate and record technical development, and from that, develop strategies to improve.

E6F2FFE7A25B4A23BD444A76C9144A29.description: Be accepting ofappropriate critiques from others, and work towards implementing the solutions to those critiques.

2A19EA1D3B9C4FA29A1F558BAC708CE2.description: Critically examine and assess the student's individual work and personal contributions to group projects/performances, with assistance as necessary.

E15C979F2CF44E809B33CF49ADCE8380.description: Show respect for the personal work of self and others through appropriate critique.

EAFA496D11FA4A46B5EF5EF9480ED461.description: Explore understanding of PA systems including set up, tone and level settings for microphones, and so on.

761A7D932A40440681E079EA2DFD9837.description: Employ the learned characteristics of different styles, eras, etc. to the performance of the student's music.

E6F97D71DD644859A50FC9F63E1C9B0F.description: Demonstrate a professional attitude towards conduct, focus and communication skills in rehearsal, preparation of materials and presentation of products.

11F1EDAC8E854AE0BCF57B65B99F0CCB.description: Develop leadership as a performer by offering help, ideas and guideance to other performers during rehearsals and sectionals.

A5D02E0F4FDA406382234E7D7719401F.description: Sing in tune with good balance and tone and be aware of the qualities of the student's own voice (e.g., range, where the break in the student's voice is).

DD4BA5C641EB477F94AA313E2A848267.description: Attend to melodic phrasing, rhythmic accuracy and articulation in perparation and performance of vocal jazz.

DDCB84EC159C4FEAA63B7E20DF4797F8.description: Know the role of each of the parts within the student's ensemble by demonstrating the ability to perform those specific tasks that are particular to the vocal part or instrument that the student sings or plays in the ensemble (e.g., bass part in the choir, comping for guitar and piano, walking lines for the bass, solo parts in the choir and position in a section).

E0C874AD377F4C7F889C11C766016DBF.description: Demonstrate the knowledge and implementation of the skills, techniques and attitudes necessary for successful ensemble performace.

FDF6A669AAC34099BA96C22DD025664E.description: Recognize and discuss the value of original thought, technical proficiency, place, era and other concepts in the music of the great jazz performers.

27AE216400D549EEAF43A715806E3D6F.description: Refine the skills and components of listening actively, continue to develop these listening skill and recognize that listening contributes to the authenticity of performances.

03DD2412600F4B0F854BE7CE409B6ADA.description: When listening to a musical selection, as a group develop the ability to describe and classify the music using appropriate jazz language (e.g., style, period, compose, culture and performer).

89C6968713EC4BCB9E87383FFC2F114F.description: With assistance or in groups, design and implement a plan for improvement (personal and ensemble) based on the criteria generated from listening to the great performers.

AD629DC0847F4B11B3C459DF5820D0D5.description: Generate criteria of excellence through listening to the music of the great performers (e.g., What is it that makes the music great? what do the great performers do that the student or student's ensemble does no do?)

4342910AAB754639A6CD2C1B4FED2DAE.description: Listen to the music of the great jazz and vocal jazz performers.

ACA3E24B2C414CFA94E7C8A3AD970CD4.description: Listen to performances of vocal jazz music and individually or with assistance develop and apply critical criteria to use in critical exaluation of one's own work and other's work.

1BE9E44085564B91A2B600B80AAB7511.description: Develp strategies for hearing 2 and 4 on first hearing a piece of music in an appropriate time signature.

FECC2FC8E86F4F94A114E4CC5CCB187E.description: Use strategies to identify the types of scales being used (pentatonic, blues, major, etc.) in music performed and/or listened to.

51A96E4C71D945329EE81967758F8DEF.description: Identify the time signatures on first hearing a piece of music, including 6/8, in addition to simpler duple time signatures. Demonstrate the patters of strong and weak beats that are identified with the time signatures

7FE4C93BEC1944069D976EE7A87113D6.description: Individually and in groups identify, experiment with, and purposefully use strategies to solve different challenges related to music making.

A77F1C5961194A9A8DB98D8F710598F1.description: Develop the skills and abilities to analyze vocal jazz music in real time while making or listening to the music.

80FF3D5C49074F9784296B1FABC0C174.description: Discuss the history, cultural heritage and effect of current events as these apply to the musical selection.

0483388C7A2D4C1EBEE7EBB956D10030.description: Listen to music analyzing and reflecting on the melody, other voices, bass line, drums and percussion, background lines, background vocals, roots and chord progression and sing with the recording.

84D7DCBC4AD34E0CA603F019846705C7.description: Analyze and reflect on just one voice or instrument from the beginning to the end of a musical selection (e.g., Does the singer or player perform the same way all the way through? How was it different or the same? What did he/she sing or play that the student also might be able to sing or play?)

1FF07C92C576422DBD5564FE9853BDF5.description: Analyze the characteristic sounds, licks, tone and other elements of well-known singers and/or groups. Identify these singers and/or groups. Identify these singers and/or groups on recordings aurally, only by listening to the characteristic sounds or ideas presented in the music.

750E102E0D924CED810735836792ED09.description: Analyze the development of the jazz music(melody, arrangement, changes, or improvisation) as a whole or in smaller sections.

CC2CA50C2F8C4C23BCE53080D10A257F.description: Listen to jazz music and with assistance analyze form, tone, style, era, dynamics, articulation, time signature, characteristic rhythms, time, balance, blend, key, monde and/or pitch.

21C5A850951B433D978168A9D318ACFE.description: Develop skills and abilities necessary to listen to jazz as a jazz performer when not personally performing the music.

7DF855128A824D81959F995D3C7C7364.description: Know, predict and/or anticipate what is next or might bve next in the music and prepare for that while performing in the moment of the music.

2A92A5E34A4A44ABA83551F8C39D7878.description: Know any special emotional context that may apply to the music, generate the appropriate emotional feeling or energy and/or synchronize the personal emotional state of the performer with the emotional context of the music being performed.

2F18800F33F349FB8FDAAF2525F26DC1.description: Recall previous experiences and knowledge (in music and in life) and integrate these into solo group vocal jazz performances.

3984559228424783A8E8CBBBE7F6E256.description: Know the history, culture, style, form and tempo of the music being performed and respond to the music by reading it and/or performing the notes and/or changes appropriately

F5141AED089A477FA03DE5B725B94470.description: React to the audience, their presence (or nor), body language, expressions and reaction to the music (e.g., applause, cheering, being asked to sing louder or quieter).

3049C678C56C4D2D9224A80896E9F9A0.description: Listen to the acoustic properties of the performing space, including the sound, tone, loudness, and reverb of the room and adjust singing and microphone technique accordingly.

9383958F5DE1403395F31325245A9DF4.description: Respond to the conductor/leader, including gestures, cues, tempo, expressions and body language.

2A59CBD4F27C4B8CBD5BE4705846FFB9.description: Immediately respond to the ensemble's response (e.g., When singing, does the student match and change vowel sounds and shapes to match the group?).

D4517B5A2766435EBFC50B5DD8466AE3.description: Respond to the rest of the ensemble (e.g., its tone, colour, pitch, dynamics, style, rhythm, time, balance, consistent vowel use and blend).

665E18068BDE478CB5470727E6084DE1.description: Respond to qualities of personal tone such as pitch, dynamics, style, colour, blend, rhythm, time, and consistent vowel use.

6045FE419C08459EB4B3C79FFB556B90.description: Develop skills and abilities required to listen and respond as a vocal jazz performer when singing jazz.

54219C78C4104F439CDC4E9A6A3B4160.description: Critical/Responsive (CR) Goal: Students will respond to artistic expressions of Saskatchewan, Canadian, and International artists using critical thinking, research, creativity, and collaborative inquiry.

96D37015229B41C8BF7B4CDB933F2063.description: Compare and contrast vocal jazz style to other vocal styles.

FD5A3D736D6242DF901D9FC55FC41A34.description: Sight-read a melodic line written in stepwise motions

B08F7B6785784FC78BAE1915471B0A2A.description: Sing a jazz standard (with recorded or live acompaniment) exploring scat singin and other appropriate jazz stylings.

2E782B918141498189DB46B6BFCB2028.description: Sing the chord tones of major and minor triads, dominant and major 7ths, and scale triads.

6B7E3FDBBAD34FC1B19F7D47FA77BD42.description: Sing one octave major, harmonic minor and blues scales, ascending and descending, unaccompanied.

3FEDF5028E064CC2B87D39A0C72FC38E.description: Sing a one octave chromatic scale, scending and descending, unaccompanied.

2F1622188423419AB91D136E63AB791D.description: Demonstrate the knowledge of good microphone techniques in rehearsals and performance of music.

9AE779F24B57474E813C4063C2963766.description: Demonstrate the key concepts related to singing expressively (e.g., work painting, phrasing, motion and dynamics). Show the knowledge of these concepts through singing.

F787B3B8B3D643D792F05BAA4FF17DF1.description: Demonstrate the connection betrween the breath and the voice.

CD8449CDA3CC4E65A1F71E569F522224.description: Demonstrate a vocal tone appropriate to the style and personal development.

7655E957D3904063AF7D3BAF846228EE.description: Explore individual vocal techniques and apply these to create or show a musical product.

E6BB933213DF4533A3DEB1777531905B.description: Identify different elements of music such as articulation, rhythm, beat, metre, time placement and tone that help create a jazz style and apply this knowledge while music making.

5CD1574184D143FC88D2590E11C9B590.description: With assistance, design, implement and evaluate a plan to improve individual performance and to enhance the knowledge and uderstanding of vocal jazz. As part of this process of improvement, include recording and listening back to performances, practices and/or rehearsals.

EC8738B520C545EA971F883AD64BDBA9.description: Explore the understanding of the relationship of form and text in music, particularly blues and ABA, AABA song forms.

FCF3FB237D8442018A5086F7BFA2DC2F.description: Sing a variety of vocal jazz styles (e.g., swing, funk, ballad) accompanied and a cappella.

877DA94256E74247BD436468B5F07C2B.description: Employ in performance the knowledge of standard notation conventions (e.g., note durations up to eighth notes, repeats, codas, D.S.s and dynamic markings). Identify jazz conventions that differ from traditional classical notation (e.g., falls, glisses, slides, inflection marks and hats).

4D4A71DBE16A444F8B4E78BE4F6BC276.description: Identify the elements of music and apply these to create a musical product.

471D22BDCBE14A46886396FA77ACC699.description: Begin to use jazz vocabulary and use this vocabulary to describe personal musical practise, learning, theory and performance (see Jazz Glossary).

80E7D9B2E77C4C9CA22371A464BA20A9.description: Develop knowledge of conventions regarding jazz articulation and use those conventions in performance.

D61EDFA5141745E0A0FB0BE6D0AFDFDB.description: Experiment with text through creating original text to pre-existing melodies and improvisations (vocalese)

98E746A6C0764E0EA0C70AD5C433C025.description: Model through performance and/or instruct through sectionals, a deep understanding of the musical text. This may include: demonstrating phrasing; describing the historical context/meaning of the text; using proper syllabic emphasis; bringing out important words in the text; connecting the music or melody to the text; describing the cultural significance of the text; telling a story with the music and text; comparing and contrasting vocal jazz style to other vocal styles.

38A0E840E3254DC2833760915CD79C55.description: Prepare, rehearse and perform music in jazz style in solo, small group and/or large ensemble settings.

E990DA4B27E24338965BC230FB24B40A.description: Integrate, with assistance as necessary, the understanding of the muscial text into a personal musical performance.

3922E3C56E6848CB8D55FCA10B93809B.description: Take personal and musical risks by trying new ways to express oneself in the jazz idiom, using new ideas, new concepts and a variety of styles.

31795007011A4CBE9A2AFC9BBBF5EB0F.description: Demonstrate improvement and growth in the presentation and construction of improvised solos in a performance setting.

3712186E34D7414DBEB3A4B967FC8E3F.description: Use text and/or scat syllables to create jazz ideas in improvisations by: using conversation, and trading 4's in converstation; creating text over blues or other forms; using a variety of jazz scat syllables.

4F89F6AA0A6242AFA2C07136CE81F49C.description: Individually and/or in groups create simple, short, three or four note jazz ideas and develop these licks by methods such as: sequencing; transforming(manipulating critical notes in a phrase to suit chord changes); adding single notes to the original lick(passing tones, approach tones, etc.) -ornamenting the lick; stylizing licks by adding turns falls, scoops, etc; Connecting licks with segments of scalesm, runs or ornamentations.

7648A889E52D481B9A21D49A97C7834E.description: Sing and/or transcribe music through methods such as: call and response with the teacher (or other students); singing roots of the chord progression of the song; singing blues heads and simple jazz tunes by ear; singing colour tones (thirds and sevenths, ninths) over blues progressions; singing a solo using a single scale or mode (blues, dorian, major etc); singing and/or playing along with recordings of solos; singing the solo being studied without the guiding vocal; and starting with short sections, such as a few bars or a single lick, gradually increasing the length and complexity being studied.

FDE6BB448143454AABB212A31624E2C3.description: Discuss understanding of jazz style and analyze musical events within a solo or composition(e.g. introduction, shout chorus, form, dynamics, pitches, changes, articulation).

5EDBAE92E7D24C64A2DE885065D3A4B1.description: Impovising in a jazz style, exploring understanding of applicable jazz theory.

3B20D45D194C4828B36FB17F5E2F7BE8.description: Creative/Productive (CP) Goal: Students will inquire, create, and communicate through dance, drama, music and visual art.
